block.p: Glass Goes Silver Heller Gallery, 420 West 14th Street; (212) 414-4014.

The 25th annual Glass America exhibition, featuring glass sculptures by more than 40 artists, starts tomorrow and continues through Aug. 19. The works will include blown glass forms by Dante Marioni that are reminiscent of Roman vessels; a sculpture by Mary Shaffer involving glass softened to look like draped fabric; and a cast glass and bronze sculpture by Daniel Clayman. Open Tuesday through Saturday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. No charge.

Walks in Manhattan Municipal Art Society, Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960.

The society will offer a series of walking tours in conjunction with ''American Modern, 1925-1940: Design for a New Age,'' an exhibition of household and decorative objects at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Jan. 7. The subjects will be the art and architecture of Rockefeller Center, Sunday and Aug. 20, at 1 p.m.; the Wall Street area, July 23 at 1 p.m.; the areas of Grand Central and Tudor City, July 30 at 1 p.m.; midtown Manhattan, Aug. 6 at 1 p.m.; and Herald and Times Squares, Aug. 13 at 1 p.m.
A complete walking tour schedule is available by calling. Fees range from $10 to $15; members, $8 to $12.
Gems and Jewelry Tiffany & Company, Fifth Avenue at 57th Street; (212) 755-8000.

Earrings, brooches, bracelets, watches and rings will be on display with decorative objects from Wednesday through Sept. 16. Among the more than 50 objects will be an 1896 perfume bottle shaped like an acorn, an 1889 writing case made of enamel, silk, garnet, gold and turquoise, and a brooch made with moonstones, platinum and diamonds. Open Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursday until 7. No charge.
Brooklyn: Future and Past Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment; (718) 788-8500.

A cruise along the Gowanus Canal on Sunday, from 9:30 a.m. to noon, to learn about its history and plans for future development, is the first of two cruises on Brooklyn waterways. The second, on July 23, from 9:30 a.m. to noon, will explore Newtown Creek, which forms the Brooklyn-Queens border. Reservations are required, extension 219. The fee for each cruise is $35 ($30 for members, students and those 65 and older).

In another program, a tour of the archaeological dig at the Hendrick I. Lott house, a Dutch-American farmhouse built in 1800, will be given on Monday, from 10 a.m. to noon. Reservations are required, extension 401. Fee, $8; members, $6; students and those 65 and older, $5.
Papermaking Dieu Donne Papermill, 433 Broome Street (near Broadway); (212) 226-0573.

Summer workshops for adults will include basic papermaking, a one-day class offered on July 26 or Aug. 16, from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. A two-day intensive class on July 29 and 30, from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., will teach participants hanga, a Japanese woodcut technique. Tuition ranges from $60 to $200; members, $50 to 180; some classes have materials fees.
A papermaking workshop for children 5 to 13 will be offered on Aug. 19 at 2 p.m. The fee is $20. Registration is required for all classes. A schedule is available by calling.
